FacilityName: Oregon Cherry Growers, Inc - The Dalles

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY-OCG THE DALLES

Oregon Cherry Growers is a processor of cherries in brine which are further processed elsewhere into maraschino and glace' cherry products. Other processing operations at this facility include fresh cherry packing, dark sweet cherry processing, and frozen dark sweet cherry processing.  Sulfur Dioxide gas is bubbled into salt water to prepare brines that preserve, firm and bleach the cherries.  This process is essential to optimize uses for the growers' fruit and preserve cherry quality.  Fresh and frozen products are stored in cold rooms and freezers using Anhydrous Ammonia as the refrigerant.  Our mission is to produce the highest quality cherry products in safe processing operations and protect our employees, our growers, our customers, the public, and the environment.

To assure that Sulfur Dioxide is handled safely, only trained, qualified operators are authorized to make cherry brine.  Oregon Cherry Growers has a long standing safety program which includes annual SO2 training for all brine making crews, Process Safety Management, meetings when a process change occurs, and continuing follow up to assure safe practices are followed and improved if possible.  Process team members assist in the annual update of our procedures and safety information.  We have had no accidental releases of Sulfur Dioxide in the last five years.

To assure that Ammonia is handled safely, only trained refrigeration mechanics operate our refrigeration systems.  Our safety program for Ammonia also includes annual training for all operators, Process Safety Management, meetings when a process change occurs, and continuing follow up to assure that safe practices are followed.

Our hazard analysis shows our worst case scenario for Sulfur Dioxide is loss of all contents of a 90 ton railcar of Sulfur Dioxide in 10 minutes.  The distance to endpoint is 25 miles.  Potential population affected is 23,000 people.   The worst case scenario for Ammonia is loss o

f 10,500 pounds in 10 minutes.  The distance to endpoint is 3.2 miles.  Potential population affected is 300 people.  The Most Likely(alternate) scenario for Sulfur Dioxide is a leak in a 5 ton cylinder valve where the quantity released is 300 pounds over 60 minutes.  The distance to endpoint is 1.7 miles.  Potential population affected is 18 people.  The most likely scenario for Ammonia is 200 pounds released in 10minutes.  The distance to endpoint is 0.43 miles. Potential population affected is 6 people.

To assure accidental releases are prevented, Oregon Cherry Growers has a continuing safety program for Sulfur Dioxide and Ammonia.  All process procedures are written and closely monitored by trained qualified employees.  These include checklists for operations, regular equipment inspections, and maintaining a stringent training program to keep operators alert to safe operations.  Emergency Response activities are reviewed and updated annually.  Emergency response training is included in pre-harvest training activities.

Planned improvements include additional coordinated training with local emergency response agencies and applying the principles of continuous improvement to all chemical handling processes.  All improvements are documented and reviewed with the process team prior to implementation.
